awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Evolution of Morphological Diversity in Primates as revealed by 3D Digital Data, Comprehensive Datasets, and Automated Phenotyping
awd_abstract_narration:
In this CAREER award Dr. Doug Boyer, along with collaborators, will collect data on primate skeletons in the form of 3D digital imagery of museum specimens and apply newly developed algorithmic methods to analyze and interpret the evolutionary meaning of those data. This research will address fundamental questions about how modern primate diversity came to be, work to refine understanding of the incremental processes that differentiated humanity from its closest relatives. As a result of this research 3D digital models will be added to Duke?s virtual museum (www.morphosource.org), which is accessible to all researchers and the public; the bioinformatics analysis tools his team is developing will enable researchers to analyze and interpret data on geometrically complex aspects anatomical diversity. Boyer will simultaneously work with education scientists connecting this virtual museum to educators and students in ways that emphasize STEM learning and Next Generation Science Standards. In addition, the virtual museum -- open to contributions from any scientist -- will provide a forum where researchers can easily disseminate their data (and theoretical advances stemming from it) to educators and public.

In Boyer's 5-year project he will execute studies targeting hypotheses central to perceptions of how primates evolved: 1) Influence of dietary ecology on primate characteristics: mechanical properties of tooth geometry will be quantified and their evolutionary tempo and mode will be modeled across living and fossil primates to see whether a diet of insects or herbaceous material has driven various episodes of diversification. The team will also evaluate whether certain other distinctive features of primate skeletons can be related to dietary needs or other biological roles by assessing patterns of covariation among all traits of interest. 2) Influence of functional constraints on patterns of evolution: Boyer and his team will determine how anatomical solutions to ecological problems in ancestral primates have affected subsequent paths of diversification by running analyses that compare magnitudes and patterns of variation among different regions of the skeleton across primates. This project will contribute multiple studies introducing a new paradigm for testing evolutionary hypotheses. Additionally, it creates a novel bioinformatics infrastructure that democratizes access to morphological datasets and enables a broader community of researchers to analyze such data, setting the stage for synchronizing morphological studies with genomic ones, and will ultimately maximizing the explanatory power of research utilizing morphology to gain insight on evolutionary processes.  In particular, molecular and evolutionary-developmental biologists will be able to evaluate the significance of morphological variation associated with genetic and gene-expression data, and biomedical engineers will be able to automate measurement protocols and evaluate variation in their data more rapidly and efficiently.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The fundamental goals of this research were to (1) document evidence relevant to understanding the changes in body plan that happened during early primate evolution, and (2) use proposed anatomical patterns to make well-supported inferences regarding physiological, functional, behavioral, and ecological changes reflecting the adaptive processes underlying primate evolutionary origins.

While addressing these goals primarily required amassing an extensive collection of 3D image data representing key extinct and extant primates, the project also focused on investing in new approaches to data management and analysis in order to break through barriers of previous research. Specifically, this project managed the image data it collected by immediately archiving and often also publishing it on MorphoSource, a 3D-specialized public repository. Handling the data this way greatly improved its accessibility over the course of the project and allowed the lab group to operate with more efficiency and agility. In addition, this practice considerably eased the burden of making large amounts of data available for the purpose of data transparency at the time of manuscript submission and publication.  The lab curated several educational datasets on MorphoSource for use in class settings. This practice became much more widespread during COVID and is the objective of multiple unrelated, ongoing outreach grants.

This project also focused on developing new analytic methods for documenting anatomical variation in 3D models of bones.  This aspect of the work was pursued in collaboration with faculty and students in Duke?s math department.

So far, this project has produced 34 published papers. It also has two more papers in review, and two papers that were submitted, reviewed and rejected. In addition, 15 conference abstracts and presentations cited this grant, though the global pandemic starting in 2020 reduced productivity in this realm. Finally, two fully documented github code repositories with well-tested and functional software for running morphometric analyses represent achievements related to this project, among others.

This project helped provide research and training experiences for four postdocs, seven graduate students, 10 Duke undergraduates, one non-Duke undergraduate intern, and two high school volunteers.

It also had positive and transformative impacts for museums and the broader research community through its archiving and sharing of data on MorphoSource. Many of the image datasets it collected represent hard-to-access specimens, meaning they were historically under-used and under-valued for scholarly activity. Now these specimens are seeing profound increases in use. For example, 3,680 image datasets primarily representing alcohol-preserved specimens from the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) have been downloaded over 21,000 times by researchers and educators around the world. Prior to this project, such wet specimens were rarely ever used for studying osteological variation, if at all. As another example, the private departmental collection of Stony brook University includes cadavers of many rare monkey species (many of which are not available from the AMNH collection). It was effectively an unused and inaccessible collection.  This collection was imaged as a data collection goal for this study and is now accessible to anyone anywhere in the world. The data for these 2-3 dozen specimens have now been downloaded over 400 times.

The 34 papers published as a result of this research have helped understand aspects of (1) cranial anatomy, brain size, and related metabolic tradeoffs in brain size evolution (Boyer et al., 2016a; Fulwood et al., 2016; Boyer and Harrington, 2018; Gonzales et al. 2019; Harrington et al., 2019); (2) postcranial morphology and its functional implications for early primate behaviors (Boyer et al., 2016b; Yapuncich et al., 2017; Boyer et al., 2018, 2019, Yapuncich et al., 2019a); (3) dental morphology and its functional implications for primate diet evolution (Fulwood et al., 2020; 2021a-b; Vitek et al., 2021; Devries et al., (in review); and (4) newly described fossil material or species and their implications for views on early primate evolution (Boyer et al., 2017; Seiffert et al., 2017; Gunnell et al., 2018; Morse et al., 2018; Boyer and Gingerich 2019; Marigo et al., 2020; Boyer et al., 2021; Harrington et al., 2021; Rose et al., 2021)

Other publications have moved the methodological landscape forward by publishing theoretical and applied findings on new ways to align, register and compare anatomical shapes using geometrically-grounded computer vision techniques and machine learning (Vitek et al., 2017; Gao et al., 2018, 2019; Shan et al. 2019; Dym et al., 2020; Rolfe et al., 2021; Frank et al., 2021; Wang et al., 2021).

Finally, three papers relating specifically to the MorphoSource database, data shared through it, or data sharing practices were published (Boyer et al., 2017; Yapuncich et al., 2019; Mulligan et al., 2022).

Despite the extensive activity on this award, the most comprehensive, and promising data projects enabled by it have yet to be published and continue (at the time of this report) to be a top priority for the PI and his lab group.


Last Modified: 09/27/2023
Modified by: Douglas M Boyer
